Monarch Butterfly Skip to main content

Monarch Butterfly

The monarch butterfly (Danaus plexippus) is one of the most recognizable and well-studied butterflies on the planet. Known for its distinctive orange and black wings, the monarch is famous for its incredible migration journey.

Biology of the Monarch Butterfly

The monarch butterfly (Danaus plexippus) is known for its distinct orange and black wings. It undergoes four life stages: egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa (chrysalis), and adult butterfly.

Monarch Butterfly Habitat

Monarch butterflies live in diverse habitats, from forests to grasslands. They rely on specific plants for survival.

Milkweed

Milkweed is essential for monarch caterpillars, as it is their only food source. Adult monarchs also lay their eggs on milkweed plants.

Other Plants

Besides milkweed, adult monarchs feed on nectar from flowers such as goldenrod, asters, and coneflowers.

Monarch Butterfly Migration

Monarch butterflies migrate thousands of miles between North America and Mexico every year to escape cold weather. This is one of the most remarkable migrations in the insect world.
